items.name: Djinguereber Mosque
items.description: Built in 1327 under the orders of Mansa Musa, this iconic mosque is one of the oldest in West Africa. It is known for its unique mud-brick construction and serves as an important religious and historical site in Timbuktu.

items.name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
items.description: Constructed in the early 15th century, this mosque is part of Timbuktuâ€™s ancient religious complex. It is famous for its legend that the doors of the mosque would remain closed until the end of time.

items.name: Sankore Mosque
items.description: Also known as the University of Sankore, this mosque was a center of Islamic learning during the Mali Empire. Scholars from across Africa studied theology, mathematics, and astronomy here.

items.name: Heinrich Barth's House
items.description: The residence of Heinrich Barth, a 19th-century German explorer who extensively documented the history, culture, and geography of West Africa during his travels.

items.name: Tomb of Askia
items.description: A UNESCO World Heritage site, the Tomb of Askia was built by Askia Muhammad I, the emperor of the Songhai Empire. It is a remarkable example of Sudano-Sahelian architecture and a significant Islamic landmark.

items.name: Cathedral of Bamako
items.description: A Roman Catholic cathedral built during the French colonial period. It is an important religious and architectural landmark in the capital of Mali.

items.name: Sahara Desert
items.description: The world's largest hot desert, stretching across North Africa. In Mali, it is home to nomadic Tuareg communities, ancient trade routes, and breathtaking dunes.

items.name: National Park of Mali
items.description: A large, scenic park in the capital city featuring botanical gardens, wildlife, walking trails, and cultural sites. It serves as a recreational and conservation area for residents and visitors.
